title: Good Omens Book List: Aziraphale
body:
• Maurice by E.M. Forster
  • The Divine Comedy by Dante Alighieri
  • Tell the Wolves I’m Home by Carol Rifka Brunt
  • Christopher and His Kind by Christopher Isherwood
  • A History of the World in 6 Glasses by Tom Standage
  • Stigmata by Helene Cixous
  • A Natural History of the Senses by Diane Ackerman
  • Leaves of Grass by Walt Whitman
  • Funny Boy by Shyam Selvadurai
  • Madame Bovary by Gustave Flaubert
  • Bright Dead Things by Ada Limón
  • A Letter to Harvey Milk: Short Stories by Lesléa Newman
  • Rebecca by Daphne du Maurier
  • Anna Karenina by Leo Tolstoy
  • The View from the Cheap Seats: Selected Nonfiction by Neil Gaiman
  • Confessions of a Mask by Yukio Mishima

blog.name: tinsnip
blog.title: No, said Aziraphale, it's ineffable.
blog.description:
Hello, I'm tinsnip.

Feeling rather ineffable these days. Expect a great deal of Good Omens.

Other interests: Star Trek. (Primarily DS9 and Cardassians.)
Pratchett. Wodehouse.
Cats. The Doctors Whom. Science. Cute things. Life truths. Pixels. And spiders, sometimes, so keep that in mind.

I post fic on AO3. It's quite good - you should have a look.

My work with Vyc on a Kardasi conlang is here.

Cardassian meta is found mostly under cardassians or kardasi.

If you enjoy my fanfic, why not buy me a coffee?

summary: god I love that trope. Crowley: fuck what do I say, how do I confess my feelings, I could destroy our entire relationship, I'm...
question: god I love that trope. Crowley: fuck what do I say, how do I confess my feelings, I could destroy our entire relationship, I'm going to implode from the stress of this. Aziraphale: hmm our 500 year anniversary of our marriage is coming up, too bad crowley never seems to remember these things. should I say something? nahhh
answer: they’re both so dumb and it Sustains me

body:

Me: Fine.
My brain: Look when Amazon said Good Omens was coming in 2019 I thought they meant January/February latest not THE END OF MAY

summary: My mom has had the biggest crush on Michael Sheen since I was 13 and made her watch all the Twilight movies with me and now that...
body: My mom has had the biggest crush on Michael Sheen since I was 13 and made her watch all the Twilight movies with me and now that I’ve told her he’s playing Aziraphale in Good Omens and showed her some pictures I think she’s just as excited for May 31 as I am.

once i finally read and probably adopt dwarvenbreadspores fic as basically canon
but this is where i'm at for the moment
summary: Anyway based on the text I have concluded that:  a). Aziraphale and Crowley thought about their son Warlock all the time while...
body:
Anyway based on the text I have concluded that: 

a). Aziraphale and Crowley thought about their son Warlock all the time while trying to save the world, God just has skewed priorities and failed to mention this in her narration. 

b). Aziraphale’s willingness to consider killing Adam to stop the apocalypse isn’t just because He’s Like That (although he is), it’s also because he was in full-on I Must Protect My Son And My Husband mode. This becomes complicated when he actually sees Adam and thinks, ‘oh no, he is also son-shaped’.

c). They are a little heartbroken when Warlock moves to America, but they always keep tabs on him and visit often. Perhaps they even relocate there temporarily, until he is grown. Warlock lives his life as a thoroughly average human in most respects, and he never quite notices the curious regularity with which pairs of older mentor figures flit in and out of his life, or understands why he immediately feels so connected and safe with these odd couples. But his life is never too much to bear nor too terribly dull, and because he knows what it is to be loved he learns also to love others, so that’s alright.

summary: Crowley stood up, a little unsteadily. He reached a hand down to Aziraphale. "Come on," he said. "I'll drive us back to London."...
body:
Crowley stood up, a little unsteadily. He reached a hand down to Aziraphale.

“Come on,” he said. “I’ll drive us back to London.”

He took a Jeep. No one stopped them.

It had a cassette player. This isn’t general issue, even for American military vehicles, but Crowley automatically assumed that all vehicles he drove would have cassette players and therefore this one did, within seconds of his getting in.

The cassette that he put on as he drove was marked Handel’s Water Music, and it stayed Handel’s Water Music all the way home.

This made me quote emotional :’(.

blog.name: they-handed-me-the-moon
blog.title: They Handed Me The Moon
blog.description: Paige, 23, she/her, queer. This blog is for whatever catches my interest, which for now is primarily Good Omens

tags: i apparently have lots of thoughts and feelings about the
3 whole lines that support my determination to read immortal Dads into the book
summary: I won’t deny Good Omens is a mass of missed opportunities when it comes to Aziraphale and Crowley interacting with children....
body:
I won’t deny Good Omens is a mass of missed opportunities when it comes to Aziraphale and Crowley interacting with children. Their one fleshed-out scene  with Warlock is a disaster, every moment they are with The Them is wasted, and the fact that within the narration they don’t think of Warlock once after they realize he is not the anticrhist is one of my top five beefs with the book.

But disappointing as all that is, it cannot erase the fact that, faced with the probable end of the world, they decide that their best hope is to use their last years to raise a child together—and they are delighted to do it.

What really gets to me about the moment they decide to raise Warlock is that they don’t even dither over it. Aziraphale hesitates over the plan and questions whether it is possible to positively influence the spawn of Satan, but there are no objections to the idea of raising a child in itself. Neither of them lament ‘sacrificing’ what may be their final years on the earth they love to childrearing, there is no sighing over how they would have preferred spending that time visiting old haunts and eating at favorite restaurants.

In fact, they are discussing the idea in the abstract as a means to save the world rather than a concrete thing they will be doing for eleven years until the final few lines of the conversation, in which the following occurs:

  • Crowley says, “it’ll be for the child’s own good, in the long run.“ Supposedly this is still part of his bid to convince Aziraphale to help save the world, but the mere fact of his saying it means he’s thought beyond the cosmic implications to what this will mean for the child. He cares about this boy not being collateral damage.
  • Crowley then adds, “"We’ll be godfathers, sort of,” in response to which “Aziraphale beamed.” He beamed. Aziraphale thinking about interfering with what he perceives as the divine plan is dithering and uncertain, Aziraphale thinking about playing a positive and meaningful role in a child’s life beams with delight.
  • Crowley finishes the exchange with, "It’s not too bad, when you get used to it.” And I don’t know how to argue for this exactly, but wishful thinking aside, coming from a character like Crowley who has a vested interest in pretending not to be excited about being a child’s godfather, even before I had a developed reading of his character this half-concession immediately translated to me as “oh, he’s excited for this too.”

So basically what I’m saying here is … Aziraphale and Crowley, two immortal beings, conclude that the world is probably going to end and that their only chance of saving it is to spend eleven years raising the son of Satan. And instead of being dismayed at being constrained to spend their probably-finally years in this manner, they seem pleased as punch about it. They actually seem to think raising a kid together before the world ends is a Good and Fun idea.

And to cap it off, they then go and have a Good and Fun time doing it.

I realize that the magician scene is against me here, and the best I can say is that Crowley is distracted and my take on Aziraphale is that he can be good with children one-on-one once he has had time to learn them on an individual level, once he stops seeing them as ‘a child’ and starts seeing them as a particular person. But trying to entertain a crowd of children, most of whom he doesn’t know, is going to be far out of his element.

However the defining image of their time with Warlock isn’t one disastrous party, but Aziraphale and Crowley meeting periodically to discuss their progress and smiling. Granted they are pleased with their progress, but there is no hint that they are displeased with the experience. Their reaction to discussing their time with Warlock is, again and again, to smile.

And then, when they leave behind their old personas of nanny of gardener, the narration informs us that “Neither of them left with quite the same spring in their step with which they’d arrived.” (And for the record I’m going to assume this is actually Aziraphale and Crowley and not people they hired). Which besides the very important fact that they began this process with a spring in their step, at this point we’ve been given no cause to believe things are going badly in terms of the plan. Maybe this line was intended to imply that they were already aware things weren’t going according to plan, but the narration suggests nothing of the sort. This moment comes immediately after the line about them smiling over the whole process, implying that to their minds  all was well, and while we don’t know when Crowley began to suspect Warlock is ‘too normal,’ Aziraphale doesn’t seem to suspect anything until Crowley communicates his fears immediately before the party. Which is to say,  I contest that the most logical reading of the actual text that they are sorry to leave behind the connection they have built up with Warlock in their first forms, even though they are about to return with new ones. They aren’t leaving for good, and yet they are mourning the end of one means of connection with Warlock.

In conclusion, am I seeing what I want to see and reading what I want to see into ambiguities? Absolutely. But I don’t think I’m twisting the text—this reading is there and I’m taking it. Aziraphale and Crowley are almost certainly disaster dads, but they are dads and they Like It and they love their son. The End.

reblog.comment:

Aziraphale and Crowley are almost certainly disaster dads, but they are dads and they Like It and they love their son. The End.

trail.content_raw:
I won’t deny Good Omens is a mass of missed opportunities when it comes to Aziraphale and Crowley interacting with children. Their one fleshed-out scene  with Warlock is a disaster, every moment they are with The Them is wasted, and the fact that within the narration they don’t think of Warlock once after they realize he is not the anticrhist is one of my top five beefs with the book.

But disappointing as all that is, it cannot erase the fact that, faced with the probable end of the world, they decide that their best hope is to use their last years to raise a child together—and they are delighted to do it.

What really gets to me about the moment they decide to raise Warlock is that they don’t even dither over it. Aziraphale hesitates over the plan and questions whether it is possible to positively influence the spawn of Satan, but there are no objections to the idea of raising a child in itself. Neither of them lament ‘sacrificing’ what may be their final years on the earth they love to childrearing, there is no sighing over how they would have preferred spending that time visiting old haunts and eating at favorite restaurants.

In fact, they are discussing the idea in the abstract as a means to save the world rather than a concrete thing they will be doing for eleven years until the final few lines of the conversation, in which the following occurs:

  • Crowley says, “it’ll be for the child’s own good, in the long run.“ Supposedly this is still part of his bid to convince Aziraphale to help save the world, but the mere fact of his saying it means he’s thought beyond the cosmic implications to what this will mean for the child. He cares about this boy not being collateral damage.
  • Crowley then adds, “"We’ll be godfathers, sort of,” in response to which “Aziraphale beamed.” He beamed. Aziraphale thinking about interfering with what he perceives as the divine plan is dithering and uncertain, Aziraphale thinking about playing a positive and meaningful role in a child’s life beams with delight.
  • Crowley finishes the exchange with, "It’s not too bad, when you get used to it.” And I don’t know how to argue for this exactly, but wishful thinking aside, coming from a character like Crowley who has a vested interest in pretending not to be excited about being a child’s godfather, even before I had a developed reading of his character this half-concession immediately translated to me as “oh, he’s excited for this too.”

So basically what I’m saying here is … Aziraphale and Crowley, two immortal beings, conclude that the world is probably going to end and that their only chance of saving it is to spend eleven years raising the son of Satan. And instead of being dismayed at being constrained to spend their probably-finally years in this manner, they seem pleased as punch about it. They actually seem to think raising a kid together before the world ends is a Good and Fun idea.

And to cap it off, they then go and have a Good and Fun time doing it.

I realize that the magician scene is against me here, and the best I can say is that Crowley is distracted and my take on Aziraphale is that he can be good with children one-on-one once he has had time to learn them on an individual level, once he stops seeing them as ‘a child’ and starts seeing them as a particular person. But trying to entertain a crowd of children, most of whom he doesn’t know, is going to be far out of his element.

However the defining image of their time with Warlock isn’t one disastrous party, but Aziraphale and Crowley meeting periodically to discuss their progress and smiling. Granted they are pleased with their progress, but there is no hint that they are displeased with the experience. Their reaction to discussing their time with Warlock is, again and again, to smile.

And then, when they leave behind their old personas of nanny of gardener, the narration informs us that “Neither of them left with quite the same spring in their step with which they’d arrived.” (And for the record I’m going to assume this is actually Aziraphale and Crowley and not people they hired). Which besides the very important fact that they began this process with a spring in their step, at this point we’ve been given no cause to believe things are going badly in terms of the plan. Maybe this line was intended to imply that they were already aware things weren’t going according to plan, but the narration suggests nothing of the sort. This moment comes immediately after the line about them smiling over the whole process, implying that to their minds  all was well, and while we don’t know when Crowley began to suspect Warlock is ‘too normal,’ Aziraphale doesn’t seem to suspect anything until Crowley communicates his fears immediately before the party. Which is to say,  I contest that the most logical reading of the actual text that they are sorry to leave behind the connection they have built up with Warlock in their first forms, even though they are about to return with new ones. They aren’t leaving for good, and yet they are mourning the end of one means of connection with Warlock.

In conclusion, am I seeing what I want to see and reading what I want to see into ambiguities? Absolutely. But I don’t think I’m twisting the text—this reading is there and I’m taking it. Aziraphale and Crowley are almost certainly disaster dads, but they are dads and they Like It and they love their son. The End.
trail.content:
I won’t deny Good Omens is a mass of missed opportunities when it comes to Aziraphale and Crowley interacting with children. Their one fleshed-out scene  with Warlock is a disaster, every moment they are with The Them is wasted, and the fact that within the narration they don’t think of Warlock once after they realize he is not the anticrhist is one of my top five beefs with the book.

But disappointing as all that is, it cannot erase the fact that, faced with the probable end of the world, they decide that their best hope is to use their last years to raise a child together—and they are delighted to do it.

What really gets to me about the moment they decide to raise Warlock is that they don’t even dither over it. Aziraphale hesitates over the plan and questions whether it is possible to positively influence the spawn of Satan, but there are no objections to the idea of raising a child in itself. Neither of them lament ‘sacrificing’ what may be their final years on the earth they love to childrearing, there is no sighing over how they would have preferred spending that time visiting old haunts and eating at favorite restaurants.

In fact, they are discussing the idea in the abstract as a means to save the world rather than a concrete thing they will be doing for eleven years until the final few lines of the conversation, in which the following occurs:

  • Crowley says, “it’ll be for the child’s own good, in the long run.“ Supposedly this is still part of his bid to convince Aziraphale to help save the world, but the mere fact of his saying it means he’s thought beyond the cosmic implications to what this will mean for the child. He cares about this boy not being collateral damage.
  • Crowley then adds, “"We’ll be godfathers, sort of,” in response to which “Aziraphale beamed.” He beamed. Aziraphale thinking about interfering with what he perceives as the divine plan is dithering and uncertain, Aziraphale thinking about playing a positive and meaningful role in a child’s life beams with delight.

So basically what I’m saying here is … Aziraphale and Crowley, two immortal beings, conclude that the world is probably going to end and that their only chance of saving it is to spend eleven years raising the son of Satan. I realize that the magician scene is against me here, and the best I can say is that Crowley is distracted and my take on Aziraphale is that he can be good with children one-on-one once he has had time to learn them on an individual level, once he stops seeing them as ‘a child’ and starts seeing them as a particular person. And then, when they leave behind their old personas of nanny of gardener, the narration informs us that “Neither of them left with quite the same spring in their step with which they’d arrived.” (And for the record I’m going to assume this is actually Aziraphale and Crowley and not people they hired). Maybe this line was intended to imply that they were already aware things weren’t going according to plan, but the narration suggests nothing of the sort. Which is to say,  I contest that the most logical reading of the actual text that they are sorry to leave behind the connection they have built up with Warlock in their first forms, even though they are about to return with new ones. They aren’t leaving for good, and yet they are mourning the end of one means of connection with Warlock.

In conclusion, am I seeing what I want to see and reading what I want to see into ambiguities? Absolutely. But I don’t think I’m twisting the text—this reading is there and I’m taking it. Aziraphale and Crowley are almost certainly disaster dads, but they are dads and they Like It and they love their son. The End.

blog.title: You'll Find Me Dreaming
blog.description: Wild Writer. Ditzy Doodler. Wailing Wayward Daughter. Kick-Ass Kingsman. Tacky Trekkie. Belligerent Bookworm. Scorpio. Panromantic Asexual. INFJ. Melancholic. Neutral Good.I'm Delaney and I love drawing, reading, writing, sleeping and cute stuff.

tags: let it be known these are all works that i have read or am in the process of reading or just seem like clear choices
all are just opinions so take them as you will
title: Good Omens Book List: Crowley
body:
• The Ideal Husband by Oscar Wilde
  • Enemy Mine by Barry B. Longyear
  • Giovanni’s Room by James Baldwin
  • The Collected Poems of Oscar Wilde by Oscar Wilde
  • Broken Monsters by Lauren Beukes
  • The Master and Margarita by Mikhail Bulgakov
  • Heart of a Dog by Mikhail Bulgakov
  • The Fatal Eggs by Mikhail Bulgakov (Really anything by him because I can imagine Crowley appreciating the absurdity)
  • Calling A Wolf A Wolf by Kaveh Akbar
  • Twelfth Night by William Shakespeare
  • All the Rage by sam sax (Read “#Melancholia” and tell me you disagree)
  • Haunted by Chuck Palahniuk
  • In Love & Trouble by Alice Walker (Especially “Entertaining God” and “The Revenge of Hannah Kemhuff”)
  • The Country Wife by William Wycherley
  • Carmilla by Joseph Sheridan Le Fanu
  • Somebody to Love: The Life, Death, and Legacy of Freddie Mercury by Mark Langthorne and Matt Richards

blog.title: Graf
blog.description:
\_(._.)_/ 20 /Ophiuchus⛎/ Russian /
Lover of stars and stories/ Commissions: open/ Trades: possible/ Glad to see you here с:

summary:
When the available cover ran out, he took a deep breath and leapt to his feet. 

"Okay, douchebags, grab some...
body:
When the available cover ran out, he took a deep breath and leapt to his feet.
“Okay, douchebags, grab some sk-ohnoooeeeeee…”
Where one of the figures had been there was something dreadful. He blacked out.
Crowley restored himself to his favorite shape.
“I hate having to do that,” he murmured. “I’m always afraid I’ll forget how to change back. And it can ruin a good suit.”
“I think the maggots were a bit over the top, myself,” said Aziraphale, but without much rancor. Angels had certain moral standards to maintain and so, unlike Crowley, he preferred to buy his clothes rather than wish them into being from raw firmament. And the shirt had been quite expensive.

- Good Omens by Terry Pratchet & Neil Gaiman

tags: i gotta tag every version of this fuckers name to make sure yall see this
my mother reacts to good omens
summary: My mother, on 'Good Omens' (novel) thus far, part 2
title: My mother, on 'Good Omens' (novel) thus far, part 2
body:
*Sister Mary trying to get Mr. Young to give the baby a Satanic name*
Her: You gotta be more subtle than that. Come on.
`
*Crowley sleeping through the 19th century*
Her: A demonic snake-man after my own heart.
`
*Newt playing with electricity*
Her: I wish David [my younger brother, who had already gone to bed] was here to listen so I could tell him he better fucking never.
`
*drunk Crowley and Aziraphale*
Her: You're too good at reading that, you know.
Me: ...
`
*Aziraphale saying dolphins are a kind of fish that mate out of water*
Her: The saddest thing is he was there at the time of creation. He should know better.
`
*Aziraphale suggesting to Crowley that the bird in his analogy take a spaceship to the end of the universe*
Her: Wow, this book is full of opportunities for Doctor Who references.
`
*the description of the skeleton-like model who asked Sable to sign her copy of his book*
Her: That sounds like how I would describe skinny people, too. Good on Mr. Gaiman or Sir Terry or whoever wrote that bit.
`
*on Crowley and Aziraphale realizing the mixing up of the anti-Christ*
Her: They wasted so much time probably really fucking that kid up mentally for nothing.
